newsitem.title: SPAIN: NATO agrees on enlargement text.
newsitem.headline: NATO agrees on enlargement text.

text.p: NATO leaders agreed on Tuesday to invite Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary to join the Western alliance and named Romania and Slovenia as deserving cases when enlargement is reviewed in 1999, a NATO official said.

He said the agreement would be announced at 5 p.m. (1500 GMT) after a compromise was reached with France, which had demanded a clearer assurance that Romania and Slovenia would be in the next wave of former communist states admitted to NATO.

Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi told reporters: "The meeting ended with a general agreement...The extension of NATO has been formally started for three countries...In the communique, explicit mention was made of the date 1999 and of enlargement to Romania and Slovenia."
French officials confirmed that President Jacques Chirac had accepted the deal after it was redrafted to include Romania and Slovenia in the paragraph containing the review clause.

The declaration recognised progress towards stability and cooperation among the states in the Baltic region without identifying Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia by name, in apparent deference to Russia's adamant opposition to their joining NATO.
